name: Kepler-168
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-168 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-168 is a star with 1.1239999999999997 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.11 times its radius. It is located 4553.14 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-168 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-168 b

Kepler-168 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.06 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 4.43 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-168.

The mass of Kepler-168 b is 2.37 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-168 b is 1.46 that of Earth. At 2.37 Earth masses, Kepler-168 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-168 c

Kepler-168 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.12 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 13.19 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-168.

The mass of Kepler-168 c is 10.34 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-168 c is 2.69 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, Kepler-168 c is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-168, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
